pullRequest.body:
The "longFile" linter is a syntax linter. It emits a warning on files which are longer than a certain number of lines
(1500 by default). A value of `0` silences the linter entirely.

This PR also modifies the `TextBased` `fileTooLong` linter: now it only lints files that do not contain `set_option linter.style.longFile `, and removes the exceptions that are now covered by the "longFile" linter.

The `TextBased` longFile linter stays (for now), though it is going to be removed soon.

---

Once #15845 lands, the text-based linter can be removed.

I tried setting the default option for the linter to 0 and then modifying it in the lakefile to be 1500 for Mathlib, but I could not get it to work.

<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [c01109e5bb](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15610/commits/c01109e5bba849760b56a360fd1bcf308f5d1461)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ longFileLinter`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.
What I feel is really missing for this linter is a test.  However, I do not know how to test it, since `eoi` is not a "normal" syntax node and `#guard_msgs in` does not latch onto it.

Two quick thoughts (I can review properly next week):
- can you add a comment to the text-based linter about this, including that many style exceptions are not necessary as these are managed by the syntax based linter, and why both linter will co-exist?
- can you update the technical debt counter as well? Currently, it counts the number of "long file" style exceptions; can you ensure to also count the number of "set_option linter.longFile" (and add these... if a shell script allows this)?
- as I said already: a syntax linter has much nicer user experience; thanks for upgrading the text-based linter even further!

Michael, thank you for the review!

I expanded the docs and comment to the text-based linters, mentioning the syntax one.

I also added the `set_option linter.longFile` count to the technical debts metrics.  This is what I see locally:
```bash
$ printf '%s|%s\n' "$(
  { grep 'ERR_NUM_LIN' scripts/style-exceptions.txt
    grep '^set_option linter.longFile [0-9]*' $(git ls-files '*.lean') ; } | wc -l
)" "large files"
66|large files
```
and it matches the number that the Zulip post has.
(Long-term, it would be nicest to have this PR *remove* the text-based linter instead, and import this linter in Mathlib.Init instead. We'll see in which order things land.)

Given that I re-wrote some of the code, I prefer to wait for a moment to give you the chance to review these changes.
If you're also happy, one of us can maintainer merge on behalf of both, or so :-)

I did not like using `default` because `default : Nat` is already 0: Lean did not get confused, but I prefer to avoid even giving it a chance of getting it wrong.

Also, I clearly did not think enough about the conditions.  I pushed something, but I'm not sure if it is correct now.

> I did not like using `default` because `default : Nat` is already 0: Lean did not get confused, but I prefer to avoid even giving it a chance of getting it wrong.
> 
> Also, I clearly did not think enough about the conditions. I pushed something, but I'm not sure if it is correct now.

:scream: I had no idea about `default`. Can you tell me more what I should be concerned about?
(What about `defaultValue`) then? I just do not find `defValue` very nice to read...

`default` is simply the name of the unique field of the `Inhabited` class (which is `export`ed to the root namespace).  Since `Nat` has an `Inhabited` instance (with default value `0`: try `#eval (default : Nat)`), writing `let default := (x : Nat)` creates a shadowing between `(Inhabited.)default` and the local `let`-bound `default`.

We can use `defaultValue`, but I preferred `defValue` because
* that is the name of the `linter.longLine` field,
* there is no actual shadowing in this case, since the option is not exported and the hypothetically shadowed values would be equal anyways!

It just felt like less baggage to carry: this natural number already has (almost) this name.

Notice that Lean gets it right in all cases: the shadowing issue is mostly for human redability, not for Lean.
I just merged master, and pushed a commit moving the linter into the `Style` namespace. Full review incoming...

Btw, we could *enforce* that `set_option linter.style.longFile x` is only followed by `#exit` or the end of the file by making the linter say something if it parses a non-terminal command when the option is not set to the default value.

Would this be an improvement?  Or is it ok if the option can be set anywhere in the file?

As I said above: checking for an early set_option sounds useful --- but only if this is fine performance-wise. The gain (avoiding a confusing, but presumably very rare scenario) is not *that* large, after all.
Otherwise: would you like to remove the text-based linter now, or shall e.g. I submit a follow-up?

I usually prefer to do the removal in a separate PR, since if, for any reason, it needs to be reverted, you can more easily revert the removal and decide if you also want to revert the addition of the new linter.

In this case: assuming CI passes now, let me
maintainer merge

Thanks a lot for your patience throughout this long review process. I am (still) very happy for the text-based linter to get rewritten in nicer form, and look forward to removing the removing ones over time :-)
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by grunweg.
bors merge

Build failed (retrying...):
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10630603722/job/29469803180)

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10631221861/job/29471671150)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10631221861/job/29471670885)
Thanks for rewriting this linter! I took the liberty to propose some wording changes directly - feel free to revert any you dislike. I have one minor comment - apart from that, this looks good to go.

Thanks Michael!

I accepted all your suggestions!
Thanks! I took a look again, realised the logic wasn't fully doing what it was supposed to do, and ended up staring at this for long enough that I fixed it myself. Careful checking is welcome :-)

Sorry for the delay; I now gave this a final look. I agree with the logic now; I merely suggested a few minor phrasing tweaks, one tweak to the logic (to mirror the text-based linter) and found one comment that seems outdated.
Michael, thanks a lot for the careful review!  I left a couple of comments and implemented the rest of the changes!

This check deserves a comment: we don't flag `Mathlib.lean`, which contains only imports.
(We would apply this to all import-only files, but I agree there is no need for now.)
Added a comment and a "future" TODO.

If I understand correctly, the last check should not be required: I think it's always true.
```suggestion
    if 1500 < linterBound && lastLine + 200 < linterBound then

I like why you're making this change: to avoid the linter proposing `set_option linter.largeFiles 1200`.

I'm not convinced this solution is best, though: I would rather suggest to remove the configuration.
That is, if `candidate < 1500`, suggest removing the `set_option` altogether.
I disallowed forcing "short" files.  I agree that currently no file is required to be short, so allowing to set a value of less than 1500 is not really justified.

That is reasonable, good idea!

I took a detailed look at this logic again: it would still *suggest* a new limit shorter than the default.
At the same time, the equality case also needs to be handled: if a file has 300 lines, but a limit of 2000, something should get printed --- ideally, a suggestion to remove the set_option. I added both.

Yes, this code is more subtle than I would like...
I think that this is fixed by the current iteration of the linter.
So did I!

```suggestion
        m!"The default value of the `longFile` linter is {defVal}. \

Do you really need the last sentence?
```suggestion
         Please, remove the `set_option linter.longFile {linterBound}`."

Update: it felt easier to just apply these suggestions myself. But do revert any you dislike!

Local testing indicates this makes the linter return - though I do not quite understand *why*. Do you know more?
Can a linter never print more than one warning?
I have a slight preference for keeping the "disable with `0`": this is what `logLint` would say.
Sure, I agree in general! Just in this case, suggesting the disabling logic feels weird when the `set_option` can just be *removed*: that is even simpler...
Ok, this feature is likely only useful in the test files: I added a comment whenever I used it there.

```suggestion
      | `(set_option linter.longFile $x) => TSyntax.getNat âŸ¨x.rawâŸ© â‰¤ defValue
```

```suggestion
  -- TODO: if there are more such files, revise the implementation.
```

Per upcoming PRs, I think it's better to move this to the style namespace.
```suggestion
namespace Style.longFile

Per the above:
```suggestion
end Style.longFile

Great that you found a way to test this! Let's add a comment about user implications: how about the following?
```
-- (This also means the linter will stop at an #exit command: if the user sets this linter option *before* the #exit, this could generate slightly confusing warnings if the linter suggests lowering the value.
-- Hopefully, in practice the linter is only changed at the end of the file, so this will not matter.)
```

I do not understand what this comment is clarifying: this is probably due to the fact that I have thought quite a bit about the linter and I am failing to see what can be confusing about it!

Can you explain what confusion this comment alleviates?  :smile:

I worried about the following scenario:
- in a long file, the set_option is set "early" (say, at the beginning of the file)
- the user temporarily writes #exit, say, to debug something
This exit is placed *after* the set_option, but early enough that *at this point*, the linter option is set too high.

Then, the linter will complain about the option being set too high --- but that complain is spurious (it will disappear once the #exit is removed) and following the warning will yield *another* (correct, non-spurious) warning when the #exit is removed again.

Granted, this scenario is a bit convoluted (and only a temporary state).
Given this, your suggestion of warning about the option being set early seems useful (if perf. allows it; otherwise, a comment should suffice).

I see.  Honestly, if someone knows that `#exit` shielded inside a `xxx in #exit` allows Lean to continue parsing the file after `#exit`, I think that they will not be confused by the linter for too long!  I would leave this as is, though I can implement the forcing the `set_option` to be the "last" command of a file, maybe after polling Zulip.
Sure - this is not something I consider essential. While minimising surprises is nice and these things add up, there are probably more useful changes one could make in that regard.
And the equality case (of setting the linter to the default value) is handled above. I am fully happy with this check now!

This is not fully true: if linterBound == defValue and lastLine <= defValue, we also end up here.
(In this case, we will not warn and all is fine. But the comment is inaccurate. This is also why the `candidate := max candidate defValue` is *necessary*.)

How about moving this comment, and the `max` line into the `else` branch below? In the first branch, it is not needed. (Did I recommend to move this check out, back then? If so, I'm sorry, and need not move it back (and just fix the comment). I do not intend to be Goldilocks' reviewer.)

`candidate` is used in this branch, since the linter suggests a value for its option with which it will be happy.

I updated the comment to include the other possibility, though.
Thanks. This looks correct now.

In the text-based linter, I used a slightly different algorithm --- which is more sticky, as it only lowers the option in steps of at least 200 lines. (Currently, this linter will warn more often, e.g. a file going from 2520 lines (with candidate of 2700) to 2480 will yield a warning. I think that's slightly overzealous.) What do you think?
```suggestion
    if candidate + 200 <= linterBound then
Great, I like this!

Not a native speaker, but is this better grammar? (If you know better, feel to ignore this/enlighten me!)
```suggestion
-- Do not allow unnecessarily increasing the `longFile` linter option

```suggestion
-- First, we silence the linter, so that we can set a default value smaller than 1500.

```suggestion
-- Next, we test that the `longFile` linter warns when a file exceeds the allowed value.

```suggestion
-- First, we silence the linter, so that we can set a default value smaller than 1500.

```suggestion
-- the linter tells us to use a smaller bound.
Maybe move this above the definition of `candidate` since it is independent?
I think that `candidate` is used in the `if` to print something in the warning.  Or am I misunderstanding what you are suggesting?
Sorry. I didn't read carefully.
I don't think x + 200 \leq x.
Oops!  The logic behind when to lint what changed so many times that this is probably a leftover from a version where it made sense!  ðŸ˜Š
I just removed the final `else ...` block.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: the longFile linter

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - fix(lint-style.py): recognise all kinds of style exceptions
[Merged by Bors] - chore: remove the text-based long file linter
